title: Sensational England stun New Zealand to reach Rugby World Cup final
text:
England will compete in next weekend’s World Cup final after a stunning win over New Zealand (Picture: AP)

England will compete in the Rugby World Cup final after a stunning 19-7 win over New Zealand.

The All Blacks were protecting an astonishing 12-year unbeaten record in the competition and going for an unprecedented third straight success, but had no answer to a stunning England performance that epitomised the togetherness and collective spirit of side superbly marshalled by skipper Owen Farrell.

England made a dream start, capitalising on a trademark burst from Anthony Watson which eventually, via succession of superb offloads from both Kyle Sinckler and Courtney Lawes, led to Manu Tuilagi crashing over from short range after just 98 seconds.

The opening 20 minutes was played at an astonishing, frenetic pace with some stunning free-flowing rugby interspersed with several handling errors which prevented England from building on their early advantage.

England momentarily thought they had extended their lead in the 24th minute when another slick passing move resulted in Sam Underhill crossing the try line, but referee Nigel Owens, with help from the TMO, decided he had benefited illegally from Tom Curry’s dummy run taking out a New Zealand tackler.

Eddie Jones’ side finally got tangible reward for their dominance on the stroke of half time when George Ford, taking over kicking duties from an apparently injured Farrell, landed a penalty from long range.

Farrell re-emerged for the second half but again handed kicking duties over, this time to Elliot Daly, but the giant full-back was unable to add the three points from halfway but an even bigger blow was to follow soon after.

After Beauden Barrett was penalised for holding on, England opted to go for the lineout and the decision looked to have paid dividends when Ben Youngs sniped through the All Black’s defence, only for the TMO to adjudge that the ball had been passed forward in the maul.

George Ford gave an immaculate kicking display to help England into the World Cup final (Picture: Getty)

England did at least edge a further three points in front when Ford again smashed over a penalty following yet more New Zealand indiscipline at the breakdown, but they were gifted a route back into the contest just before the hour mark.

The underdogs had been utterly faultless at the lineout but a stray throw from Jamie George was gobbled up by Ardie Savea and the New Zealand No.7 only had to flop over the line but a New Zealand onslaught failed to materialise.

Ford provide a much-needed instant response by slotting another penalty after more sensational work from England’s forwards and added another three points to leave New Zealand needing two scores with just 12 minutes remaining.

The All Blacks failed to even threaten to cut the deficit, however, and were left to contemplate the end of their long, long reign as the sport’s dominant force.
